Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Volar Locking Plate Fixation in Low-Grade Open vs. Closed Distal Radius Fractures

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 60 patients were enrolled

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients with Gustilo and Anderson Type I or II open DRFs.

Intervention.evidence: 20 in the open fracture group and 40 in the closed fracture group

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether volar locking plate fixation in low-grade open distal radius fractures (DRFs) yields outcomes comparable to those in closed DRFs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH) score, assessed at 3 months and 1 year postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 60 patients were enrolled, with 20 in the open fracture group and 40 in the closed fracture group

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 3 months, the closed fracture group demonstrated superior wrist flexion, extension, grip strength, and DASH scores. By 1 year, no significant differences were observed between the groups in any functional outcome measure.

Harms.evidence: Infection rates and other complications were similar, with no severe adverse events reported.
